takeaways.title: Public finance alone cannot meet the $4 trillion annual clean energy investment needed by 2030. Private sector involvement is essential to scale innovations, accelerate renewable energy deployment, and achieve cost efficiencies globally.

While private sector investment in clean energy is increasing globally, developing countries lag significantly. These regions attract less than 15% of global clean energy investments despite their high renewable energy potential and urgent energy access needs.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: credit ratings & borrowing costs
concepts.body: Credit ratings are assessments of the creditworthiness of a borrower, indicating the likelihood of default on debt obligations. Borrowing costs refer to the interest rates and fees that borrowers must pay to obtain loans, which are influenced by their credit ratings.

concepts.title: debt sustainability
concepts.body: Debt sustainability refers to the ability of a borrower, typically a government or organization, to manage and repay its debt without requiring external assistance or defaulting, ensuring that debt levels remain stable relative to income or economic growth.

concepts.title: thematic bond
concepts.body: A thematic bond is a type of bond issued to finance projects that have a specific social or environmental theme, such as renewable energy, education, or healthcare.

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

In this lesson, learners explore the growing role of thematic bonds, such as green and climate bonds, in financing sustainable energy projects. The lesson examines how public and corporate sectors are utilizing these bonds to raise capital specifically for environmental and renewable energy initiatives. It also explains the mechanics of bond issuance, investor motivations, and the impact of these instruments on the clean energy sector. By the end, learners will understand how thematic bonds contribute to aligning financial markets with global climate and sustainability goals.

Labeled or thematic bonds — such as green, blue, social, sustainable, transition, and sustainability-linked bonds, which promote sustainability and better Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) performance, are becoming an important part of financial markets and highlight the key role debt markets can play in funding and inspiring companies to contribute to sustainability. As an increasing number of investors look to align their portfolios with sustainability goals globally, it is important to understand how labeled bonds may help to achieve ESG as well as risk-return objectives in portfolios. Green, blue, sustainable, or sustainability-linked bonds (SLB) can help mitigate climate change risks and have the potential to generate attractive risk-adjusted returns. Social bonds on the other hand can finance new and existing projects with positive social outcomes. Hence, labeled bonds can help align investors’ asset allocations with their ESG and financial performance objectives. These instruments are not just available within sustainable and impact strategies, integrated ESG investors use them as well, if the pricing is attractive.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Types of Thematic Bonds

content.text: There are two distinct groups with labeled bonds:
1: Use of Proceeds (UoP) bonds,

such as green or social bonds, to fund projects with specific and dedicated environmental and/or social benefits. Adhering to standards and predetermined UoP categories is key to understanding their impact.
2: Key Performance Indicator (KPI) bonds,

such as sustainability-linked bonds, do not finance particular green or social projects but the issuer sets ambitious, realistic, and explicit sustainability targets that it seeks to meet. The coupon payments are linked to meeting their sustainability performance targets (SPTs), with the interest payments typically increasing if the targets are not met.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | A
content.title: A. Green Bonds

content.text: Green bonds are UoP bonds, devoted to financing new and existing projects or activities with positive environmental impacts. Green bonds should be issued in line with the Green Bond Principles (GBP), a set of voluntary guidelines that promote more transparent, unified reporting on the bonds’ environmental objectives and estimated impact that were put forward by the International Capital Market Association (ICMA). Examples of project categories eligible for green bond issuance include renewable energy, energy efficiency, clean transportation, green buildings, wastewater management, and climate change adaptation.
Green Bond Principles (GBP)

The Green Bond Principles (GBP), updated as of June 2022, are voluntary guidelines that recommend transparency and disclosure and promote integrity in the development of the green bond market by clarifying the approach for the issuance of a green bond. The GBPs are intended for broad use by the market: they provide issuers with guidance on the key components involved in launching a credible green bond; aid investors by ensuring the availability of information necessary to evaluate the environmental impact of their green bond investments; and assist underwriters by moving the market towards standard disclosures, which will facilitate transactions. The GBP consists of four core components, including use of proceeds, project evaluation and selection, management of proceeds, and reporting. Moreover, GBP also recommends getting pre-issuance second-party opinions and post-issuance third-party eternal reviews.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | B
content.title: B. Social Bonds

content.text: Social Bonds

Social bonds are also UoP bonds where the proceeds must finance or refinance social projects or activities that achieve positive social outcomes and/or address a social issue. In many cases, social projects are aimed at target populations such as those living below the poverty line, marginalized communities, migrants, unemployed, women and/or sexual and gender minorities, people with disabilities, and displaced persons. Similar to green bonds, issuance of social bonds is oriented by a set of voluntary guidelines — in this case, the Social Bond Principles (SBP) from ICMA — aimed toward improved disclosure and transparency in the social bond market. They also arm investors with the information necessary to evaluate the social impact of their investments. Since 2020, we have seen a new type of social bond emerge in the form of COVID-related pandemic bonds. These bonds have UoP terms specifically aimed at mitigating COVID-19-related social issues and are particularly focused on the populations most impacted. Examples of project categories eligible for social bonds include food security and sustainable food systems, socioeconomic advancement, affordable housing, access to essential services, and affordable basic infrastructure. Social projects can include related and supporting expenditures such as research and development and, in situations where projects also have environmental benefits, issuers may determine the classification to be a social bond based on the primary objective of the underlying project.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | C
content.title: C. Sustainability Bonds

content.text: Sustainability Bonds

Sustainability bonds are UoP bonds meant to finance or refinance a combination of green and social projects or activities. These bonds can be issued by companies, governments, and municipalities and should follow the Sustainability Bond Guidelines from ICMA, which are aligned with both the GBP and SBP. They can be unsecured, backed by the creditworthiness of the corporate or government issuer, or secured with collateral on a specific asset. Examples of project categories eligible for sustainability bonds include those in the green and social bonds categories.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | D
content.title: D. Sustainability-linked Bonds (SLBs)

content.text: Sustainability-linked Bonds (SLBs)

Sustainability-linked bonds are any type of bonds who’s financial and/or structural characteristics can vary depending on whether the issuer achieves predefined sustainability or ESG objectives. In that sense, issuers are thereby committing explicitly (including in the bond documentation) to future improvements in sustainability outcome(s) within a predefined timeline. In other words, SLBs are forward-looking, performance-based instruments. The objectives are (i) measured through predefined KPIs and (ii) assessed against predefined Sustainability Performance Targets (SPTs). The proceeds of SLBs are intended to be used for general purposes, hence, the use of proceeds is not a determinant in its categorization. Progress, or lack thereof, toward the selected KPIs results in a decrease or increase in the instrument’s coupon. These bonds can play a key role in encouraging companies to make sustainability commitments at the corporate level, particularly through aligning to the UN SDGs or Paris Agreements.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Uruguay

content.text: Sustainability-linked Bond in Uruguay In October 2022, the Republic of Uruguay introduced an innovative Sustainability-linked Bond featuring a two-way coupon step structure. This bond's performance is linked to the achievement of two key performance indicators (KPIs):(a) A reduction in Greenhouse Gas (GHG) emissions (b) Preservation of natural forests, serving as a proxy for the country's carbon capture capacity The government has appointed UNDP as the official verifier responsible for assessing the attainment of these KPIs. The first KPI speaks to Uruguay efforts at decarbonization. The country has made considerable progress decarbonizing the electricity sector. Uruguay significantly boosted its renewable electricity generation, reaching 94% in 2020, up from 64% in 2012, with a mix of wind, hydro, biomass, and solar energy sources. However, there are ongoing challenges in decarbonizing other sectors, especially transportation, where energy use remains predominantly fossil fuel-based. Uruguay has laid out ambitious plans to transition to clean energy in transport, supported by robust policies and initiatives to achieve the specified KPI.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | E
content.title: E. Transition Bonds

content.text: Transition Bonds

Transition bonds are specifically tailored towards facilitating brown-to-green transition in various industries and sectors, including energy, transport, mining, and heavy industries. These bonds support investments in energy efficiency, cleaner technologies, and carbon capture and storage solutions. Since 2022, the issuance of transition bonds has gained momentum. These bonds aim to fund projects that lead to substantial reductions in carbon emissions and environmental impacts, thereby promoting renewable and clean energy investments. In 2022, China led the global issuance of corporate green transition bonds, totaling USD 19 billion. These funds were directed towards decarbonization projects in high-emitting sectors, helping to support the country's ambitious carbon neutrality goals. Transition bonds could be structured either as a use of proceeds bond (a class of bonds like green, social and sustainability bonds) where proceeds of bond issuance are solely used for the purpose of the transition activity or as a sustainability-linked bond (SLB), also known as Key Performance Indicator (KPI) bond, where the use of proceeds is not strictly ring-fenced but used more generally, provided issuers adhere to the well-articulated KPIs and associated performance targets (upon which issuers may benefit from a potential pay for performance - mostly in the form of a more favourable interest rate or cost of funding)

The market for transition bonds is expected to grow as more countries and companies seek to meet their climate goals. For instance, Japan has been at the forefront of developing and issuing transition bonds, which are designed to support the country's ambitious climate goals while fostering economic growth in traditionally high-emission sectors. The Japanese government, through its Financial Services Agency and Ministry of the Environment, Ministry of the Environment, Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry, Ministry of Finance, and Cabinet Secretariat, has established a comprehensive framework (Japan Climate Transition Bond Framework) for these bonds, aligning them with the International Capital Market Association (ICMA) Green Bond Principles and the Climate Transition Finance Handbook. This alignment ensures high standards of transparency and impact reporting. The proceeds from these bonds are directed towards a variety of projects, including low-carbon buildings, transportation, battery technology, solar cells, wind energy, and R&D in innovative areas like hydrogen use in steelmaking.

In Latin America, Chile has also been at the forefront of using transition bonds. Chile has issued sustainability-linked bonds associated to the reduction of greenhouse gases and the increase of renewable energies within its energy matrix. An SLB could have greater impact than a green bond for overall climate goals because its performance indicators are tied to Chile’s commitments under the Paris Agreement, not just one specific project. With strong KPIs, SLBs offer financial incentives and signal to investors that Chile’s economy is becoming greener, which can help lower risk premiums.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 1 | E
content.title: F. Convertible Bonds and Contingent Convertible Bonds (CoCo bonds)

content.text: Convertible Bonds and Contingent Convertible Bonds (CoCo bonds)

CoCo bonds are another means of raising scaled finances, particularly for corporates. This would be particularly suitable for energy companies that are currently state-owned but could gradually transition to the private sector over a period. CoCo bonds would raise proceeds through a debt issuance but will have a clause for its conversion to equity in the future. CoCo bond issuances of state-owned energy companies could be complemented by gradual opening up of the energy sector for private sector investments and competition enveloped by a sound and independent regulatory purview. One of the important aspects of CoCo bonds is that bonds would not have to be repaid. Their eventual conversion to equity would mean that the initial debt obligation would be repaid not in cash but as an equity stake in the enterprise.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 2
content.title: Part 2: Challenges With Thematic Bonds

content.text: Despite their potential, the effectiveness of thematic bonds in driving significant change in developing economies faces numerous challenges.
1: Additionality and Credibility

There is skepticism about whether these bonds fund genuinely suppory new projects or merely re-label existing investments. Issues of greenwashing persist due to inconsistent standards and lack of robust verification mechanisms .
2: Institutional Capacity

Weak Regulatory Frameworks: Many developing countries lack strong regulatory frameworks to support the issuance and management of thematic bonds. This includes deficiencies in governance, transparency, and accountability, which are essential for maintaining investor confidence and ensuring the effective use of funds . Limited Financial Expertise: Financial sectors in many developing countries may not have the necessary expertise to structure, issue, and manage thematic bonds effectively, limiting their ability to leverage these instruments and attract international investors.
3: Market Fragmentation and Standardization

Lack of Unified Standards: The absence of universally accepted standards and taxonomies leads to market fragmentation, making it difficult for investors to compare and assess bonds across different regions and issuers. Moreover, this gap may lead to concerns over "transition-washing"– where the environmental benefits of the bonds are overstated or unclear. Clear guidelines and standards are essential to ensure these bonds are used effectively and avoid "transition-washing". Investor Demand and Perception: Investors require transparency and verifiable impact metrics to commit to thematic bonds. Inconsistent reporting and verification standards can lead to skepticism and lower demand from investors who prioritize environmental, social, and governance (ESG) criteria .
4: Financial and Market Risks

Currency and Exchange Rate Risks: Issuing bonds in local currencies can help mitigate exchange rate risks, but local bond markets in many developing countries are not deep or liquid enough to support large-scale issuances. Sovereign and corporate issuers in these regions often face higher borrowing costs due to perceived credit risks . High Borrowing Costs: Developing countries often face higher borrowing costs due to lower credit ratings and perceived political and economic instability. This can make thematic bonds less attractive compared to traditional forms of debt .

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Re-designing Thematic Bonds

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | A
content.title: A. Donor Supported Modules

content.text: The donor-supported model can enhance both the effectiveness and fairness of financing sustainable development in developing economies. Central to this model is the provision of robust credit enhancements from development banks or other official sector partners, which include guarantees or insurance to mitigate the perceived risks associated with thematic bonds. This risk reduction makes the bonds more attractive to private investors, particularly institutional investors with longer investment horizons, thereby lowering borrowing costs for developing countries. The influx of private capital, coupled with reduced borrowing costs, enables these nations to secure the necessary long-term capital for green projects, making thematic bonds a more viable and attractive financing tool. For instance, In Mozambique, the World Bank’s guarantee for the Mphanda Nkuwa hydroelectric project reduced investment risks, attracting substantial private sector participation. This guarantee covered potential losses, significantly lowering borrowing costs and making the project viable for private investors . Additionally, the model emphasizes the importance of capacity building and intertemporal fiscal flexibility. Technical assistance from Multilateral Development Banks will help developing economies design and implement effective green transition strategies, ensuring that the funds raised through thematic bonds are used efficiently. For instance, in Vietnam, capacity-building programs supported by the Asian Development Bank have helped local governments develop the skills needed to issue and manage thematic bonds, leading to successful bond issuances that attract international investment.

The model's flexibility in fund allocation and timing, inspired by the EU’s NExtGeneration EU (NGEU) GB model, allows for early access to funds and extended periods for accounting green expenditures. This flexibility accommodates the diverse fiscal conditions and capacities of different developing countries, ensuring that all countries, regardless of their immediate financial constraints, can benefit from the funds allocated for sustainable projects. Such an approach ensures that no country is left behind due to its fiscal limitations . To further enhance the credibility of thematic bonds, rigorous verification mechanisms will be implemented to track both project-level and aggregate sustainability performance, addressing greenwashing concerns. Implementing rigorous verification mechanisms to track sustainability performance and tying financial incentives to ambitious targets ensure that all participating countries are held to consistent standards. This transparency and accountability prevent greenwashing and ensure that the benefits of the bonds are distributed based on actual performance and commitment to green policies. Such mechanisms promote fairness by rewarding genuine efforts and contributions to sustainable development goals . Moreover, by lowering borrowing costs through credit enhancements, the donor-supported model makes thematic bonds a viable financing tool even for countries typically excluded from global markets. This inclusivity is essential for promoting fairness as it opens up opportunities for all developing countries to benefit from sustainable finance, ensuring that no country is left behind due to its financial standing .

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | B
content.title: B. Enhanced Regulatory Frameworks

content.text: Establishing universally accepted standards, guidelines, principles, frameworks and taxonomies is crucial for ensuring transparency and credibility. International cooperation can help harmonize standards, reduce market fragmentation, and increase investor confidence. Organizations like the International Capital Market Association (ICMA) and the Climate Bonds Initiative (CBI) play key roles in developing and promoting these standards . The introduction of frameworks like the ICMA Climate Transition Finance Handbook is a great step toward addressing these issues by providing comprehensive guidelines for the effective use of transition bonds. Moreover, implementing rigorous governance frameworks and ensuring transparent processes for project selection, fund allocation, and impact measurement are essential. This includes third-party verification and standardized impact reporting to ensure that projects financed by thematic bonds deliver their promised benefits. Thematic bonds hold significant potential to mobilize capital for sustainable development, but their transformative impact in developing economies is limited without additional support and innovative frameworks. A multi-faceted approach that includes donor support, enhanced regulatory frameworks, capacity building, and the development of local currency bond markets is essential to maximize the benefits of thematic bonds and ensure they contribute effectively to global sustainability goals.

Issuing thematic bonds in local currencies offers a strategic approach to mitigating exchange rate risks and enhancing return stability for investors. This mechanism is particularly crucial in developing economies where currency volatility can deter investment. By issuing bonds in local currencies, issuers can attract a broader range of investors, including local pension funds and insurance companies, who are less concerned about currency fluctuations. This approach also stimulates the development of domestic capital markets, fostering economic growth. A notable case is Colombia which issued its first sovereign green bonds, becoming the first emerging-market economy to place these securities through local auctions in local currency and to adopt the German green twin bonds approach in the domestic market.[A1] [1] However, challenges such as market depth, credit risk, and regulatory barriers remain. Addressing these can ensure the success of local currency thematic bonds in other developing countries.

content.intro: M4: Financing Just Energy Transition | Chapter 4 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Green Sukuk- Indonesia

content.text: Indonesia aims to achieve its net zero emissions (NZE) target by 2060, as stated in the country’s updated National Determined Contributions (NDC). As a country with the highest Muslim population and the limitation of its national budget. Indonesia pioneered Green Bond and Green Sukuk as one of the key levers to achieve its NZE ambitions. The country firstly implemented a budgeting system for climate change, also known as the climate budget tagging, which identifies government expenditures that deliver specific climate change benefits according to the Government of Indonesia’s climate objectives. This budget tagging results are being used to initiate new financial instruments initiative in combating climate change in the form of Green Bond and Green Sukuk. Green Sukuk, also known as Islamic Bond, is a sharia-compliant bond where all the proceeds go exclusively to finance or re-finance green projects that are closely related to climate change mitigation and adaptation and biodiversity. The project focus is mainly around renewable energy, resilience to climate change and disaster risk areas, sustainable agriculture, waste to energy & waste management, and sustainable transportation. Therefore, this innovative financial instrument supports Indonesia’s commitment in reducing emissions based on Islamic Law principles. The two implementing actors in Indonesia’s Green Sukuk includes the Ministry of Finance and the Ministry of Energy and Mineral Resources. As each of the Ministry has different interests and roles, one as the issuer of the sovereign green sukuk and the other one as the project owner in the renewable energy sector, respectively, the on-the-ground implementation requires good coordination between the ministries. To overcome this issue, there are three policy frameworks determining the flow of finance mechanisms, namely the state budget, law on Sovereign Sukuk and its subordinate legislation, and the Republic of Indonesia Green Bond and Green Sukuk Framework.

As a result, Indonesia has become a leader in global sustainable investment by becoming the first sovereign green sukuk issuer in the world with the issuance amounting to $1.25 billion and recently, in May 2022, reached $1.5 billion issuance. One of the most successful Green Bond and Sukuk initiative is the financing of rooftop solar photovoltaic (PV) systems. Through this project, the country has driven the deployment of clean energy solutions by the public and private sectors, contributing to the country’s climate change mitigation efforts. As a result, the project generated 150 kWp (kilowatts-peak) of solar power and reduced up to 137 tonnes of greenhouse gas emissions. By issuing Sukuk, Indonesia has been able to tap into the growing pool of ethical and faith-based investors who seek investment opportunities that align with their values. This has not only helped Indonesia access a wider range of funding sources but has also reinforced the country’s commitment to sustainable development while adhering to Islamic principles. To date, Indonesia’s Green Bond and Sukuk initiative have supported numerous projects spanning various regions including Kalimantan, East Nusa Tenggara, West Papua, East Java and Maluku, with a total of $1.96 billion [5]. One of the lessons learned from this initiative is the importance of tax incentive that could be a catalyst which directly touches issuers and investors to boost the green bond/sukuk issuance.

The successful implementation of Green Sukuk in Indonesia is supported by UNDP through the sharing of in-depth knowledge and experience on different kinds of innovative financing, unlocking and leveraging Islamic finance to bridge the SDG funding gap, and helping religious funding & financing organizations to address poverty and inequality. The Asian Development Bank has also been supporting Indonesia’s Green Sukuk initiatives by being a knowledge partner and acting as investor, issuer, and guarantor. Indonesia’s green sukuk is a successful example of the pioneering role of governments in leveraging private finance for green and sustainable development. Not only in Indonesia, but Malaysia also has a growing trend of Green Sukuk issuance. Both countries have their own set of standards and frameworks, which are known as the Green Bond and Green Sukuk Framework (Indonesia) and the Sustainable Responsible Investment (SRI) Sukuk Framework (Malaysia). Learning from these two countries, although there is a great potential for replicating Green Sukuk in more countries, it is important to consider the customization of standards and frameworks that are different for each country, before issuing Green Sukuk.
